title.narrative: Sustain Darfur: Addressing the Root Causes of Crisis in Darfur

description.narrative: One of the main drivers of local conflict and poverty in the Darfur region in Sudan is availability of water. This project will contribute to improved well-being and health of people living in rural areas in Darfur. By improving access to and reliability of water, improving productivity and reliability of livelihoods and reducing conflicts, the project aims to give more people opportunities within Darfur, thus reducing the need for people to migrate to other areas. This project will be implemented by the Aqua4Darfur partnership, comprised of five Sudan-based (international) NGOs (ZOA as lead agency, International Aid Services, Practical Action, SOS Sahel Sudan and World Relief) and two Netherlands-based specialist organisations: Acacia Water, a company specialising in hydro(geo)logical analysis, and RAIN Foundation, an NGO specialising in rainwater harvesting. ZOA as Lead Agency will publish on behalf of this consortium.

The expected outcome of the project is increased availability of water for drinking and livelihoods, and improved sanitation and hygiene behaviour for communities in rural areas of Darfur. By reducing scarcity and improving water governance, the project will also contribute to reduction in tension and conflict over access to water between different community groups. By improving the reliability of water availability for people, livestock and crops, the project will contribute to enhanced resilience to climatic shocks and trends. The project has five outputs: • Output 1 Inclusive mechanisms for Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM) are in place in targeted catchment areas • Output 2 Sustainable access to safe drinking water. • Output 3 Behaviour change for improved sanitation, hygiene and nutrition practices. • Output 4 Sustainable access to water and improved production methods for crops and livestock. • Output 5 Action learning to promote replication of IWRM.
The project intends to benefit 250,000 people in rural catchment areas in the states of North, South and West Darfur.

participating-org.narrative: ZOA as Lead Agency for this consortium

transaction.ref: Expenditures ZOA and PCU until 30 September 2020

title.narrative: Impact: Improved well-being and health of people living in the targeted rural areas of Darfur
Impact indicator 1: Prevalence rate of diarrhoeal diseases among under five children in targeted localities
Impact indicator 2: Malnutrition rates among under five children
Output 2: Sustainable access to safe drinking water
Output indicator 2.1: Number of drinking water points renovated, upgraded and/or constructed with a functioning well-trained WUC

comment.narrative: 8 handpumps (North Darfur), 23 handpumps and 1 water yard (West Darfur).

title.narrative: Output indicator 2.2: Water conservation infrastructure constructed with active management & maintenance
Output 1: Inclusive mechanisms for IWRM are in place in targeted catchment areas
Output indicator 1.1: Catchment-level Water Resources Management Committees functioning with active participation of nomadic pastoralists and women

location.ref: North Darfur, South Darfur, West Darfur

comment.narrative: Update Q4 2018. This number is lower compared to what was previously reported. This is related to the progress on the CLTS and establishing Community Health Promotors. Only once this has been put in place, the accurate number of households is recorded. Previous numbers were based on estimated numbers of households in villages. A second reason is related to how we have collected data, and the numbers reported previously included sanitation as well.
North Darfur:50,000 South Darfur: 30,000, West Darfur: 80,000
Update Q4 2019. North Darfur: 9,036, South Darfur: 20,166, West Darfur: 40,158

title.narrative: Output 5: Action learning to promote replication of IWRM
Output indicator 5.2: Number of seminars, fora, and conferences in Sudan and elsewhere at which experiences are shared

comment.narrative: 1. IHSA conference 2. Analysis of climate patterns and their impacts was shared at a seminar organized by LandAC in Utrecht, the Netherlands on 7 December 2017 3. Analysis of climate patterns and their impacts was shared at the Planetary Security Conference in The Hague, the Netherlands, on 12-13 December 2017. 4. Participation at ISMAR conference in Madrid (May 2019) 5. Presentation by IWRM Expert on 2nd IWRM Water conference in Sudan organised by UNESCO/UNICEF on 2/3 December 2019. 6. Water Resources Engineer of PCU participated in a Water conference organised by the government on 30 and 31st December 2019. Some of the water harvesting experiences were used in a paper that was presented. 7. Head of PCU presented about the IWRM Group coordination at the Water Conference ‘Harnessing the Promise of the Water Sector for a prosperous New Sudan’ on 18th and 19th February 2020, organised by the Ministry of Irrigation and Water Resources. Update Q2 2020.

1. Project approach and experiences were shared at the WASH sector meeting in Khartoum on 6th September 2. Participation in the brainstorm sessions on the new WASH strategy for Sudan: IWRM got included on the agenda. 3. Analysis of climate patterns and their impacts was shared at a seminar organized by LandAC in Utrecht, the Netherlands on 7 December 4. Analysis of climate patterns and their impacts was shared at the Planetary Security Conference in The Hague, the Netherlands, on 12-13 December.

title.narrative: Output indicator 5.1: Number of technical papers produced and shared with relevant stakeholders

comment.narrative: 1. Draft of ‘Putting catchment-level IWRM into practice’ by Bromwich and Gaasbeek 2. Final of ‘Rainfall patterns in the Sahel and their implications for medium-term food security’ by Dr. T.J. Gaasbeek. Update Q2 2020.
This progress cannot be measured yet as we are in the early stages of the project.
Update Q4 2018. 2 draft technical papers have been written, but not yet published.
